awd_titl_txt: Fundamental Physics from Astronomy and Cosmology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Lisa Randall at Harvard University.

Professor Randall will conduct research on dark-matter physics and more generally on physics beyond the so-called Standard Model which explains the behavior of the elementary particles down to the smallest length scales ever probed in collider experiments.  Professor Randall's research will include studies of partially interacting dark matter, a theoretical framework which posits the existence of certain components of dark matter which interact under the influence of dark forces beyond those in the Standard Model.   Such dark-matter components, if they exist, could potentially give rise to galactic shapes and structures which might be detectable through detailed dynamical measurements.    Professor Randall will also pursue alternative ideas for addressing the long-standing hierarchy problem of particle physics.  This is the problem of explaining why the recently discovered Higgs particle is so much lighter than our current understanding of fundamental physics would suggest.    Such questions have broad scientific impact in that they attempt to address basic questions about the nature of matter and the symmetries and structure of space and time.    This science has traditionally been very strong within the United States, and this project will further advance the national interest by reinforcing research in these directions.   Professor Randall will also conduct this research in collaboration with postdoctoral researchers and graduate students, thereby helping to produce a scientifically educated and technically advanced workforce. Professor Randall will also give public lectures about this work which will be seen by the general public.

More technically, Professor Randall will work with a student and a postdoctoral fellow to determine how well the ideas described above can be advanced with available and future statistics. In the case of dwarf galaxies, the questions apply both to the data and to the simulations that will be available. In the case of partially interacting dark matter there are probes within our galaxy (such as GAIA) and outside our galaxy (such as the vast plane of satellites in Andromeda, for example) that can address these questions. For the hierarchy problem, Professor Randall will investigate extensions of the ideas and methods involving extra dimensions and dynamical theories to see if improved solutions can be found, particularly those that can be tested at future colliders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our work related to cosmological observations (Hubble tension, searching for dark matter (DM) through indirect detection with antideuterons, shape of dwarf galaxies, eccentricity for black hole binaries), and theory (de Sitter space in string theory, time-dependent solutions with mismatched branes, using geometries I previously developed to understand entanglement).

 

With NSF-supported postdoctoral fellows, we used evolving scalar fields to ease the tension between local measurements of the Hubble parameter and those obtained from cosmic microwave background measurements. We identified solutions with simple asymptotic behavior, which improved and corrected previous work that relied on coarse-grained fluid descriptions.

 

With an NSF-supported student, I revisited DM detection with antideuterons. This approach presents a unique channel for indirect detection, targeting DM that annihilates into hadrons with minimal background interference. We showed that cosmic ray antideuteron detection experiments represent one of the best ways to search for hidden sector thermal relic DM and investigated a vector portal DM that annihilates via a massive dark photon.

 

With a student, I detailed a method to measure the correspondence between DM models and observations of stellar populations within Local Group dwarf spheroidal galaxies that assumed no parametric stellar distribution. We calculated the consistency of DM and stellar kinematic models with stellar positions and line-of-sight velocities. Our method can be used to search for signals of standard and exotic DM distributions.

 

Eccentricity is a useful tool for helping to identify the origin of black hole mergers, but eccentric templates can be computationally expensive. We outlined a method for estimating the signal-to-noise ratio for inspiraling binaries at lower frequencies, such as those proposed for LISA and DECIGO.

 

With a postdoctoral fellow, we explored generating de Sitter space from higher‐dimensional geometry, especially to KKLT‐type constructions and their 5d implications. Even in the probe approximation with small g_s, a consistent higher‐dimensional solution requires a deformation of a modulus field playing the role of a Goldberger‐Wise stabilizing field in Randall‐Sundrum type geometries that occurs through a shift in the throat length. We identified the light radion field that sets the length of the throat, whose origin is the dynamical conifold deformation parameter.

 

With a postdoctoral fellow, we argued that effective actions for warped compactifications can be subtle, with large deviations in the effective potential from naive expectations owing to constraint equations from the higher-dimensional metric. Having argued that the uncorrected naive effective potential for the conifold in the Klebanov-Strassler background would be destabilized by antibranes placed at the conifold infrared tip unless the flux was uncomfortably large, we showed this result is too strong because the formerly neglected constraint equations eliminate the features of the potential that allowed for the instability in the de Sitter uplift of the KKLT scenario.

 

With a professor at University of Washington, I studied Randall-Sundrum two brane setups with mismatched brane tensions. This introduced a new class of time-dependent solutions with the potential to address cosmological issues and provide alternatives to conventional inflationary/contracting scenarios.

 

Late-time dominance of entanglement islands is important in addressing the information paradox for black holes in AdS coupled to an asymptotic non-gravitational bath. To gain insight into how this observation can be extended to gravitational systems, we explored how this story was modified within the context of Karch-Randall braneworlds when we allowed the asymptotic bath to couple to dynamical gravity. We found that the entanglement entropy of radiation emitted into the bath is a time-independent, consistent with recent work on black hole information in asymptotically flat space. When we instead considered an entanglement entropy between two sectors of a specific division of the Hilbert space, we found non-trivial time-dependence, with the Page time a monotonically decreasing function of the brane angle, provided both branes are below a particular angle. The properties of the entropy depended discontinuously on this angle, which was the first example of such discontinuous behavior for an AdS brane in AdS space.

 

In ordinary gravitational theories, any local bulk operator in an entanglement wedge is accompanied by a long-range gravitational dressing that extends to the asymptotic part of the wedge. Islands are the only known examples of entanglement wedges that are disconnected from the asymptotic region of spacetime. We showed that the lack of an asymptotic region in islands created a potential puzzle that involved the gravitational Gauss law, independently of whether there was a non-gravitational bath. We showed that this tension was resolved because islands appear in conjunction with a massive graviton. We studied the entanglement structure of a holographic BCFT background. We showed that Jackiw-Teitelboim gravity could be naturally realized in the Karch-Randall braneworld. The role of the dilaton in Jackiw-Teitelboim gravity is played by the radion in a suitably orbifolded version of the setup.

 

This research included many interesting results from observational astronomy and some interesting theoretical ideas where the warped geometries I previously developed played a big role.
